Está obsesionado con que su hija no pare en una silla obstétrica que tenía, pues lo uno es tan seguro y no lo otro. Y decídselo así de mi parte al duque, que no consiento otra cosa que el haberos detenido tanto en el parir y la congoja que él tuvo de ello, con razón, cierto lo causó la silla. Y vos nunca os deis prisa sino cuando viniere. Y de las veces que sabéis que yo he visto, os puedo dar estos buenos consejos.
utterances.text_en: She writes a letter to Catalina Micalá giving her super-advanced advice on how to give birth, she who has already been giving birth for six months, and she wants to know how good you have been in childbirth, and rightly so, since it was long and I am told it was laborious, although you do not tell me so. And it would always be if you gave birth in a chair and not on a stretcher, because it is a very dangerous thing to get into the chair early. And I believe that this was the cause of the death of the princess, my first wife. And to your two mothers, we now clarify this, that they always gave birth on a stretcher. You see how well it happened to them, which is certainly the best and safest thing. And since, as you have begun, it is to be believed that you will give birth many other times, in any case it will always be on a stretcher and not in a chair. You are obsessed with your daughter not giving birth in an obstetric chair that she had, because the one is so safe and not the other. And tell the duke so from me, that I do not consent to anything other than having detained you so much in childbirth and the distress that he had about it, with good reason, the chair certainly caused it. And you never hurry except when he comes. And from the times that you know that I have seen, I can give you this good advice.

utterances.speaker: C

Entonces su madre afectiva realmente fue Ana de Austria. La cosa es que Felipe segundo está obsesionado en que su hija no pare en ningún caso con esa silla obstétrica que encontra un dibujo de la silla cómoda. No se veía cómoda, no se veía la silla. Pero claro, con tantas turras que recibía sobre su cuerpo, Catalina se convirtió no solo en una avispadísima estratega política, sino que supo también ejercer un control súper minucioso sobre su cuerpo. Y en las más de 700 cartas que se conservan entre ella y su marido, Catalina le da al duque constantemente información detallada sobre cómo avanzan las criaturas, que así las llama, que es un poco alien, me hace bastante gracia. Las criaturas dentro de su cuerpo. Y le habla sin tapujos de cosas que ahora nos pueden sorprender un montón. Le habla sin tapujos de la regla, si le viene o le deja de venir, cuántos días le dura. Os podemos contar en primicia que a Catalina Micaela la regla le duraba ocho días. Que es un montón.
utterances.text_en: And when he refers to the two mothers, this is very because as Elizabeth of Valois dies very soon, then Philip II remarries Anne of Austria in 1570, when the infants were four 3 years old. So their affectionate mother was really Anne of Austria. The thing is that Philip II is obsessed that his daughter does not stop in any case with that obstetric chair that found a drawing of the comfortable chair. It did not look comfortable, the chair was not seen. But of course, with so many turras that she received about her body, Catherine became not only a very astute political strategist, but she also knew how to exercise a very meticulous control over her body. And in the more than 700 letters that are preserved between her and her husband, Catherine constantly gives the duke detailed information about how the creatures are progressing, which is what she calls them, which is a bit alien, it's quite funny to me. The creatures inside his body. And she talks to him off the cuff about things that may surprise us a lot now. She talks openly about her period, whether it comes or stops coming, how many days it lasts. We can tell you for the first time that Catalina Micaela's period lasted eight days. Which is a lot.

utterances.speaker: C
utterances.text: Es un montón.

utterances.speaker: B
utterances.text: Que es una barbaridad. No os va a faltar ni un dato de la intimidad de todas las personas del barroco. No había nada de asepticismo. Por ejemplo, en julio de 1589, Catalina estaba un poquillo preocupada porque no volvía a sangrar normal después del parto y comenta que los médicos han decidido hacerle una sangría en el pie, que al parecer era un tratamiento súper común, o sea, eso no le sorprende nada. Es como un tratamiento súper común y súper habitual para que regresara el flujo menstrual, cosa que no entiendo, no entiendo.
utterances.text_en: That it is an outrage. You will not miss a single piece of information about the intimacy of all baroque people. Catherine made her husband a participant in all her menstruation, pregnancy and breastfeeding processes, to levels that, in fact, might seem a little lurid to us today. There was nothing aseptic about it. For example, in July 1589, Catherine was a little bit worried because she was not bleeding normally again after childbirth and she said that the doctors had decided to give her a bloodletting in her foot, which apparently was a very common treatment, so she was not surprised at all. It is like a super common and super usual treatment to bring back the menstrual flow, which I don't understand, I don't understand.

utterances.speaker: C

utterances.text: Sangrar, desangramos del pie. utterances.text_en: Bleeding, we bleed from the foot. And after she was bled, Catherine sends him, wrapped in a small piece of cloth, she sends her husband the wooden strip where she had rested her foot during the procedure, as physical bleeding proof that she was taking all the necessary steps to return to fertility.

utterances.speaker: C

Y vos, la menor, hacéis bien en tomar caldos de raíces, como me decís, con que espero que estaréis muy buenas. Al photocall como Georgina. Pero su cuerpo, lógicamente y tristemente, no resistió esa cantidad ingente de partos. Y a los 30 años se muere. Parece que su muerte, y aquí volvemos a lo que estaba diciendo Carmen antes, que quizá Catalina Micaela fue más parecida de lo que más más favorita de lo que parecía, porque su muerte afectó fuertemente a Felipe Segundo, que moriría tan solo un año después de su hija. Un cronista de la época aseguraba que cuando Felipe tuvo noticia de la muerte de su hija, decí hizo muchísima impresión en él. Este toque que Dios le envió hizo extremos nunca vistos, sintiólo demasiadamente. Fue de suerte que dicen sus criados y privados que nunca, para siempre jamás, por muy adversa que fuese la cosa que le sucediese, le vieron hacer semejante sentimiento como ahora. Well, despite the fact that Catherine Micaela herself declared to have an iron health, and this is very strong because she always resumed the political negotiations from Turin, a few days after having given birth, she was already writing letters again, doing negotiations at the photocall, like Georgina. At the photocall like Georgina. But her body, logically and sadly, did not resist that enormous amount of childbirths. And at the age of 30 she died. It seems that her death, and here we return to what Carmen was saying before, that perhaps Catalina Micaela was more similar than more favorite than she seemed, because her death strongly affected Felipe Segundo, who would die only a year after his daughter. A chronicler of the time assured that when Felipe had news of his daughter's death, he said it made a great impression on him. This touch that God sent him went to extremes never seen before, he felt it too much. It was so much so that his servants and privates say that never, forever and ever, no matter how adverse the thing that happened to him was, did they see him make such a feeling as he did now. Neither the death of his children, nor of his wife, nor the loss of his army, nor anything else he felt like this. Nor had they ever seen him complain to this great prince as he now complained in this case and thus took away many days of his life and health.

utterances.speaker: C
utterances.text: ¿Ves? Es que yo creo al final, Ana, que Catalina Micaela era la favorita, la favorita del rey y la favorita nuestra. Porque al fin y al cabo, Ana, de quién hemos estado hablando esta obra. Ya.

Jo, es bastante tierno. ¿Se refiere eso Felipe Segundo a cuando Catalina Micaela y el duque se embarcaron en Barcelona después de aquella rabieta que ya hemos dicho? ¿Y es que yo pienso que en esa boda, en realidad me la imagino un poco como sabes la película esta, Ana, el padre de la novia, en la que Steve Martin lleva fatal que su hija, que era su ojito derecho, se case? ¿Tú la llegaste a ver?

Now seriously, I think he loved her very much. Look, he says later, three years after the famous tantrum in Barcelona, he writes to her, he tells her yesterday it was three years ago that you got pregnant and that I don't see you, that it has not given me little loneliness now and I know that I can rightly have it from you, because of how much you love me and I love you.
